SubTopics: Develop models to describe the atomic composition of simple molecules and extended structures.
Content: A student creates a ball-and-stick model to represent the atomic scale of a substance.
problems/MOG8S/media/1a.jpg
Which of these BEST describes the model?

B.Choice: 1 element with 10 molecules

C.Choice: 10 molecules representing 10 elements

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to describe a simple model for waves that includes how the amplitude of a wave is related to the energy in a wave.
Content: The drawings show two waves.
problems/MOG8S/media/2a.jpg
problems/MOG8S/media/2b.jpg
Which statement BEST compares these two waves?

A.Choice: Wave 1 has a higher frequency because it has a longer wavelength than wave 2.

B.Choice: Wave 1 has a higher frequency because it has a higher amplitude than wave 2.

C.Choice: Wave 2 has more energy because it has a higher amplitude than wave 1.

D.Choice: Wave 2 has more energy because it has a higher frequency than wave 1.

SubTopics: Develop an argument supported by evidence for how multicellular organisms are organized by varying levels of complexity; cells, tissue, organs, organ systems.
Content: Choose the correct words to best describe relationships between interacting parts of the human body.

The human body is composed of systems with interacting parts. Organ systems are made of :M-1: , which are composed of specialized cells that work together to form :M-2: . Each cell of the human body contains :M-3: with a specific function.

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to describe that waves are reflected, absorbed, or transmitted through various materials.
Content: During an experiment, a teacher uses a flashlight and shines the light toward a pane of clear glass with a black iron backing. A diagram of the experiment is shown.
problems/MOG8S/media/4a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Describe the path of the light as it travels from the flashlight to the air.
Describe the path of the light as it travels from the air to the pane of clear glass.
Explain why the students would NOT see the light travel through the black iron backing.

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's history.
Content: A scientist hiking in a desert observes a cliff. The scientist makes a drawing of the layers of rock in the cliff and the types of fossils observed in the layers. Based on observations, the scientist determines layers 3 and 5 were formed from cooled lava. The scientistâ€™s drawing is shown.
problems/MOG8S/media/5a.jpg
problems/MOG8S/media/5b.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Identify the oldest layer in the rock cliff and explain your reasoning for the layer chosen.

B.Choice: layer 2

C.Choice: layer 3

Content: Explain how the environment has changed over time at this location. Include evidence in your explanation.
A scientist claims that volcanic eruptions caused dinosaurs to become extinct at this location. Decide whether you agree or disagree with the scientistâ€™s claim and then explain your decision.

B.Choice: Disagree

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data to determine scale properties of objects in the solar system.
Content: A student makes a model of the solar system on a poster board. The student uses foam balls to represent objects in the solar system. The studentâ€™s model is shown.
problems/MOG8S/media/6a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Explain one error concerning the size of the foam balls in the model.
Explain one error concerning distances between foam balls in the model.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data on natural hazards to forecast future catastrophic events and inform the development of technologies to mitigate their effects.
Content: The graphs show the average global air temperatures and global fossil fuel consumption from about 1860 to 2000.
problems/MOG8S/media/7a.jpg
problems/MOG8S/media/7b.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Describe the overall pattern of change in average global temperatures from 1860 to 2000.
A student claims the change in average global air temperatures is a result of burning fossil fuels. Explain whether the studentâ€™s claim is plausible based on the data.
Describe TWO possible changes to the environment most likely caused by the pattern shown in the average global air temperatures.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential energy are stored in the system.
Content: One student is drawing a model to represent the investigation for Setup 1. Complete the studentâ€™s model.
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
On which shelf will the ball have the most potential energy?

B.Choice: 2-meter shelf

C.Choice: 1-meter shelf

Content: Which type of force causes the ball to have the most potential energy?

B.Choice: magnetic

C.Choice: gravitational

Content: Which direction of the force causes the ball to have the most potential energy?

B.Choice: Down

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential energy are stored in the system.
Content: Based on the data collected for Setup 2, a student made the following claim about the energy of the ball.

:box:Student Claim

As the ball travels down the ramp the kinetic energy increases and the potential energy stays the same.
Which statement BEST evaluates the studentâ€™s claim?

A.Choice: The claim is incorrect because the potential energy increases when the speed of the ball increases.

B.Choice: The claim is incorrect because the potential energy of the ball is being transferred to kinetic energy as it travels down the ramp.

C.Choice: The claim is correct because the speed of the ball increases, causing the ball to remain in motion as it travels beyond the ramp.

D.Choice: The claim is correct because the speed of the ball is the same as its kinetic energy, and the speed of the ball increases as it travels down the ramp.

SubTopics: Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an objectâ€™s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the mass of the object.
Content: A student adds a material to the ramp that causes less friction between the ramp and the 1-kilogram ball. The student plans on rolling the ball from the top of the modified ramp.
Choose the correct words or phrases to complete the statements that BEST predict the results from using the modified ramp.

Less friction acting on the ball will create :DD-1: forces resulting in the speed of the ball to :DD-2: as it travels down the ramp. The ball traveling down the modified ramp with less friction will have :DD-3: the ball traveling down the first ramp.

SubTopics: Apply physics principles to design a solution that minimizes the force of an object during a collision and develop an evaluation of the solution.
Content: A student shapes a piece of clay into a small cube. The student places the clay cube at the bottom of the ramp in Setup 2. The student rolls the 1-kilogram ball down the ramp and observes the collision between the ball and the clay cube.
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Select one variable the student could change to Setup 2 to reduce the force of the ball during the collision.

A.Choice: Replace the wood ramp with a ramp made of smoother material.

B.Choice: Reduce the height of the ramp from 1 meter to 0.5 meters.

Content: Which statement provides the BEST support for the variable you selected in Part A?

A.Choice: This would decrease the force of friction acting on the ball causing it to increase in speed.

B.Choice: This would increase the force of friction acting on the ball causing it to decrease in speed.

C.Choice: This would increase the potential energy of the ball resulting in an increase in kinetic energy.

D.Choice: This would decrease the potential energy of the ball resulting in a decrease in kinetic energy.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential energy are stored in the system.
Content: The student switches the ball used in Setup 1 with a ball that has a mass of 2 kilograms. Another student states that the potential energy of the 2-kilogram ball would be the same as the potential energy of the 1-kilogram ball since they would be placed at the same heights.
Which statement BEST explains whether the studentâ€™s statement is correct or incorrect?

A.Choice: The statement is correct because the gravitational force acting on objects with different masses is the same.

B.Choice: The statement is incorrect because an object with more mass has less potential energy due to increased air resistance.

C.Choice: The statement is incorrect because more force is needed to lift an object with more mass to the same height as an object with less mass.

D.Choice: The statement is correct because the potential energy of any object with mass is based on an objectâ€™s height above the ground and the speed at which it travels.

SubTopics: Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.
Content: A student rolls a 3-kilogram ball down the same ramp used in Setup 2. The speed of the ball after 2 seconds was 4 meters per second. The student concludes that the kinetic energy of the 3-kilogram ball is identical to the 1-kilogram ball after it has rolled down the ramp for 2 seconds.
Explain whether the studentâ€™s conclusion is correct or incorrect. Use evidence from the investigation to support your answer.

B.Choice: Incorrect

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Choose organisms to complete the model of the food chain that occurs in the Yellowstone ecosystem.
Choose the phrases to BEST describe the model in Part A.
This food chain model shows the :DD-1: in the ecosystem.

SubTopics: Construct an argument supported by empirical evidence that explains how changes to physical or biological components of an ecosystem affect populations.
Content: The table shows the change in the size of willow tree stems in sample areas of the Yellowstone ecosystem between 1995 and 2010.
problems/MOG8S/media/15a.jpg
Which conclusion about the number of beaver colonies between 2000 and 2010 is BEST supported by the data?

A.Choice: The number of beaver colonies decreased because the amount of available food for beavers decreased.

B.Choice: The number of beaver colonies increased because the beavers adapted to a change in the food sources available.

C.Choice: The number of beaver colonies increased because the amount of available resources for food and shelter increased.

D.Choice: The number of beaver colonies decreased because the beavers were unable to use the resources for food and to build shelters.

SubTopics: Construct an explanation that predicts the patterns of interactions among and between the biotic and abiotic factors in a given ecosystem.
Content: Grizzly bears, black bears, eagles, and ravens are scavengers in the Yellowstone ecosystem. Based on the information, which statement explains how the reintroduction of wolves has MOST LIKELY affected the populations of scavengers?

A.Choice: Scavenger populations likely decreased because wolves prey on scavengers.

B.Choice: Scavenger populations likely decreased because wolves and scavengers compete for the same resources.

C.Choice: Scavenger populations likely increased because wolves provide a food source for scavengers.

D.Choice: Scavenger populations likely increased because wolves provide habitat for scavengers when the wolves create and abandon their dens.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for the effects of resource availability on individual organisms and populations of organisms in an ecosystem.
Content: Which statement BEST explains how the reduction in the elk population might have affected the bison population?

A.Choice: Fewer elk led to fewer bison being preyed on by wolves.

B.Choice: Fewer elk consumed young trees, increasing the food available for bison.

C.Choice: Fewer elk led to an increase in competition for resources between elk and bison.

D.Choice: Fewer elk consumed young trees, decreasing the variety of food sources available for both species.

SubTopics: Construct an explanation that predicts the patterns of interactions among and between the biotic and abiotic factors in a given ecosystem.
Content: How can beaver activity change conditions in the Yellowstone ecosystem to result in an increase in the beaver population?

A.Choice: by building dams that continue to slow the water and encourage willow trees to grow

B.Choice: by building dams that reduce the height of the water so that more willow trees can grow

C.Choice: by helping willow trees grow taller so that they become more useful for beavers when they build dams

D.Choice: by helping to move soil from streambanks so that more willow trees will fall into the water and create natural log da

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.
Content: Identify where the components should be placed in the model to show the relationships between living and nonliving components of the Yellowstone ecosystem.
problems/MOG8S/media/19a.jpg
Match each component in one of the boxes in the model.

SubTopics: Construct an argument supported by empirical evidence that explains how changes to physical or biological components of an ecosystem affect populations.
Content: Less snow falls during a warmer-than-normal winter in the Yellowstone ecosystem. The thinner snow cover on the ground allows for more plants to be visible than when the snow cover is thick.
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Describe how a winter with less snowfall might affect the populations of willow, aspen, and cottonwood trees.
Describe how a winter with less snowfall might affect the population of elk.

Some scientists predict that, over time, the average thickness of the snow cover in the Yellowstone ecosystem will decrease as global air temperatures increase. Predict a long-term effect of the reduced snow cover in the Yellowstone ecosystem on the beaver population. Be sure to support your prediction using evidence.

SubTopics: Evaluate benefits and limitations of differing design solutions for maintaining an ecosystem.
Content: Scientists in a different area with an ecosystem similar to that of Yellowstone are considering different solutions for protecting trees in hopes of restoring the ecosystem to its previous levels of biodiversity. One scientist recommends placing fences that are two meters in height around areas of existing trees rather than introducing wolves to the ecosystem.
Choose one likely advantage and one likely disadvantage of using fences to protect the trees.

SubTopics: Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.
Content: A student is comparing characteristics of three toy cars.
problems/MOG8S/media/22a.jpg
Choose words or phrases to complete the following sentence based on the data provided in the table.
As the :DD-1: increases, the kinetic energy of the car :DD-2: .

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data on the properties of substances before and after the substances interact to determine if a chemical reaction has occurred.
Content: Students are given two solid substances and two liquid substances to mix together in different combinations. The data table shows the initial observations and final observations for each combination of substances.
problems/MOG8S/media/23a.jpg
Identify whether a chemical reaction or a physical change occurred when the substances were combined.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data to determine scale properties of objects in the solar system.
Content: The chart shows some distances between objects in the universe.
problems/MOG8S/media/24a.jpg
Compare distances in the universe by identifying where each measurement should be placed in the model from longest to shortest.

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to describe the function of a cell as a whole and ways parts of the cells contribute to that function.
Content: The diagrams show a plant cell and an animal cell.
problems/MOG8S/media/25a.jpg
problems/MOG8S/media/25b.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify TWO organelles that are present in plant cells that are absent from animal cells.
Organelle 1: :FR-1:
Organelle 2: :FR-2:
Explain why one of the organelles identified in Part A is NOT necessary for animal cells to survive.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential energy are stored in the system.
Content: A student draws a diagram to model the potential energy of objects. The diagram includes three rubber spheres of equal mass, one ramp, and one shelf.
problems/MOG8S/media/26a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify TWO spheres that have the same potential energy. Explain how this can be determined from the diagram.

B.Choice: Sphere 2

C.Choice: Sphere 3

Content: Identify the sphere which has the LEAST potential energy.

B.Choice: Sphere 2

C.Choice: Sphere 3

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earthâ€™s mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes and human activity.
Content: The map shows how North America looked approximately 100 million years ago. There are five main areas labeled on the map.
problems/MOG8S/media/27a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify the main areas of North America on the map where people would expect to find 100-million-year-old sedimentary rocks that contain fossils of microscopic ocean organisms.

B.Choice: Hudson Seaway

C.Choice: Laramidia

Content: Oil and gas are formed from the remains of microscopic ocean organisms. A student claims that the oil and gas deposits in Missouri are about 100 million years old. Based on the map, decide whether you agree or disagree with the studentâ€™s claim and then explain your decision.

B.Choice: Disagree

SubTopics: Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an objectâ€™s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the mass of the object.
Content: The diagram shows the forces applied to a stone sphere on a smooth surface.
problems/MOG8S/media/28a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Describe the motion of the stone sphere based on the forces shown in the diagram.

The same sphere is placed on a rough surface, and the same horizontal forces are acting on the sphere. Describe how the motion of the sphere will MOST LIKELY change when the stone sphere is placed on the rougher surface.

SubTopics: Interpret graphical representations to support explanations of how natural selection may lead to increases and decreases of specific traits in populations over time.
Content: Use the graph to answer the question.
problems/MOG8S/media/29a.jpg
Select TWO statements that would BEST explain the change in horsesâ€™ body mass over millions of years.

B.Choice: There was decreased food availability.

C.Choice: Horses with larger body masses were less likely to survive and reproduce.

D.Choice: Horses with larger body masses were more likely to survive and reproduce.

E.Choice: Large body mass occurred in individuals as they became adults.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret evidence from the fossil record to infer patterns of environmental change resulting in extinction and changes to life forms throughout the history of the Earth.
Content: A scientist finds a site that contains fossils of Orohippus, Mesohippus, and Miohippus.
problems/MOG8S/media/30a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify the species of horse fossils that would be found in the uppermost layer of rock. Use data from the chart to explain your answer.

B.Choice: Mesohippus

C.Choice: Miohippus

Content: Identify the species of horse fossils that would be found in the bottommost layer of rock. Use data from the chart to explain your answer.

B.Choice: Mesohippus

C.Choice: Miohippus

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variations of traits in a population increase some individuals' probability of surviving and reproducing in a specific environment.
Content: During the period when aurochs existed on Earth, they were preyed on by large predators. Some individual aurochs had stronger muscles than others. Using an understanding of natural selection, which statement explains why there would MOST LIKELY be an increase in the stronger-muscle trait in a population of aurochs?

A.Choice: Individuals with stronger muscles have a large body mass, and they would be preyed on more than other aurochs.

B.Choice: Since having stronger muscles is an inherited trait, it would be passed on to every individual in the population that was not preyed on.

C.Choice: Individuals with stronger muscles would be more likely to run away from predators, and this trait would be passed on to their future offspring.

D.Choice: Since having stronger muscles would require individuals to consume more food, they would be more exposed to predators than the other aurochs.

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variations of traits in a population increase some individuals' probability of surviving and reproducing in a specific environment.
Content: There have been studies of a population of cattle that had once been raised by people and then released into the wild. Over hundreds of years of the cattle being in the wild, the average length of their horns increased. Currently an adult maleâ€™s horn can be over 165 centimeters in length.
Choose words or phrases to complete the explanation of why the length of horns of these cattle most likely increased while they were living in the wild.
The population of cattle likely had :DD-1: genetic variation causing :DD-2: . Long horns are a :DD-3: trait. Cattle with longer horns are :DD-4: able to survive and reproduce.

2:A.Choice: all cattle to have long horns

2:B.Choice: some of the cattle to have longer horns than others

SubTopics: Construct an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors as well as specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.
Content: Some birds will eat corn seeds and teosinte seeds. The chart shows the characteristics of these two types of seeds.
problems/MOG8S/media/33a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Corn and teosinte plants are grown in the same area. Which type of plant would likely be more successful at producing offspring that would develop into new plants?

B.Choice: teosinte

Content: Select TWO reasons to support your answer in Part A.

B.Choice: The seeds have a protective structure.

C.Choice: The seeds are more easily consumed by birds.

D.Choice: The seeds that fall to the ground are difficult for birds to see.

E.Choice: The seeds remain on the plant rather than falling to the ground.

SubTopics: Gather and synthesize information about the technologies that have changed the way humans influence the inheritance of desired traits in organisms.
Content: Scientists have developed new techniques for producing organisms with desirable traits. Genetic modification allows scientists to insert genetic material from one organism into another organism. For example, one type of genetically modified corn contains genetic material from a species of bacterium. The genetically modified corn plants produce a specific substance that causes pests to die when they feed on these corn plants.
Which statement BEST describes how genetic modification technology differs from the technique used with teosinte plants thousands of years ago?

A.Choice: Genetic modification technology is available to more people.

B.Choice: Genetic modification technology requires a longer time to create a change in a species.

C.Choice: Genetic modification technology introduces completely new traits into an unrelated organism.

D.Choice: Genetic modification technology influences which traits are passed from parents to offspring.

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy from the Earthâ€™s interior drives convection which cycles Earthâ€™s crust leading to melting, crystallization, weathering and deformation of large rock formations, including generation of ocean sea floor at ridges, submergence of ocean sea floor at trenches, mountain building and active volcanic chains.
Content: Based on the hotspot theory diagram, choose words or phrases to correctly complete the statement.
Energy from :DD-1: causes :DD-2: and the movement of the :DD-3: .

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy from the Earthâ€™s interior drives convection which cycles Earthâ€™s crust leading to melting, crystallization, weathering and deformation of large rock formations, including generation of ocean sea floor at ridges, submergence of ocean sea floor at trenches, mountain building and active volcanic chains.
Content: The mountains in the Hawaiianâ€“Emperor Seamount Chain are experiencing both constructive Earth processes that build land and destructive Earth processes that break down land.
Identify whether each of the sentences below describes a constructive or a destructive Earth process.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of the past plate motions.
Content: Select THREE statements that provide evidence to support that the hotspot theory could explain the formation of the Hawaiianâ€“Emperor Seamount Chain.

A.Choice: Older islands are farther from the hotspot than younger islands.

B.Choice: Younger islands are farther from the hotspot than older islands.

C.Choice: The oldest mountains in the Hawaiianâ€“Emperor Seamount Chain are islands.

D.Choice: The oldest mountains in the Hawaiianâ€“Emperor Seamount Chain are seamounts.

E.Choice: The age of the mountains increases as the distance between the mountains and Hawaii increases.

F.Choice: The age of the mountains increases as the distance between the mountains and Hawaii decreases.

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy from the Earthâ€™s interior drives convection which cycles Earthâ€™s crust leading to melting, crystallization, weathering and deformation of large rock formations, including generation of ocean sea floor at ridges, submergence of ocean sea floor at trenches, mountain building and active volcanic chains.
Content: Order each event to show the correct sequence of events in the development of Koko Seamount.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of the past plate motions.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.

Using the information from the map, make a graph to compare the approximate distance from Hawaii and approximate age of the mountains in the Hawaiianâ€“Emperor Seamount Chain. In your graph, be sure to include data from the seven mountains.
Choose words or phrases to correctly make a conclusion based on the data in the graph.
As the Pacific Plate moves :DD-1: , the age of each mountain :DD-2: as the distance from the hotspot :DD-3: .

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence for how geoscience processes have changed Earthâ€™s surface at varying time and spatial scales.
Content: The Pacific Plate has not always moved in the direction that it is moving today. Based on the information from the map, which statement explains when the Pacific Plate MOST LIKELY changed direction?

A.Choice: The direction changed about 25 million years ago because the mountains changed from islands to seamounts.

B.Choice: The direction changed about 35 million years ago because there are fewer mountains in the chain before that age.

C.Choice: The direction changed about 40 million years ago because the pattern in the location of mountains changed.

D.Choice: The direction changed about 65 million years ago because Suiko Seamount is the oldest mountain.

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence for how geoscience processes have changed Earthâ€™s surface at varying time and spatial scales.
Content: Which statement BEST explains how erosion transforms an island into a seamount?

A.Choice: Energy from the sun causes sediments to be deposited on the island and compacted into sedimentary rock.

B.Choice: Energy from the sun causes the movement of wind and water, which transports sediments from the island to the ocean.

C.Choice: Energy from Earthâ€™s interior causes sediments to be deposited on the island and compacted into sedimentary rock.

D.Choice: Energy from Earthâ€™s interior causes the movement of wind and water, which transports sediments from the island to the ocean.

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data on natural hazards to forecast future catastrophic events and inform the development of technologies to mitigate their effects.
Content: One of the volcanoes on the island of Hawaii is experiencing volcanic activity. A team of researchers at a volcanic monitoring site recorded two types of earthquakes for three months.
problems/MOG8S/media/42a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Describe a recommendation the researchers should make to people in the area about the risk for eruption events in April after the most recent activity in March.

Based on the data, describe a difference in the warning time given to people preceding volcanic events compared to the warning time preceding a tornado. Explain how the warning time can have a positive effect on mitigating the hazards of a volcanic eruption.
